    4D-Printed Dynamic Materials in Biomedical Applications: Chemistry, Challenges, and Their Future Perspectives in the Clinical Sector

    SUBJECTS:
    • Biomaterials,
    • 3D printing,
    • Hydrogels,
    • Materials,
    • Polymers
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Most of the biomedical materials printed using 3D bioprinting are static and are unable to alter/transform with dynamic changes in the internal environment of the body. The emergence of four-dimensional (4D) printing addresses this problem. By preprogramming dynamic polymer materials and their nanocomposites, 4D printing is able to produce the desired shapes or transform functions under specific conditions or stimuli to better adapt to the surrounding environment. In this review, the current and potential applications of 4D-printed materials are introduced in different aspects of the biomedical field, e.g., tissue engineering, drug delivery, and sensors. In addition, the existing limitations and possible solutions are discussed. Finally, the current limitations of 4D-printed materials along with their future perspective are presented to provide a basis for future research.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Three-dimensional (3D) printing is an innovative technology that has been used in the medical sector for applications such as tissue and organ fabrication, regenerative medicine, and drug delivery devices.(1â3) This technology has also attracted increasing interest due to its advantages in providing personalized medical services through the printing of patient-specific biological devices according to personal data.(4â6) Although the 3D structures of biomaterials successfully mimic the structure of physiological geometry, most of the biomedical materials printed using 3D bioprinting technology are static and are unable to change with alterations in the surrounding dynamic environment. Biomaterials should adapt to the dynamic physiological environment over time to solve this problem. Hence, four-dimensional printing has emerged to overcome this issue.
    The concept of four-dimensional (4D) printing was first proposed by Tibbits as a dynamic material that is able to transform its shape over time.(7) Compared with 3D printing, the additional dimension in 4D printing was defined as âtimeâ, due to a change in the shape or function of the advanced materials over time in a specific environment and in response to stimulation.(8,9) Advanced 4D printing materials, also known as 4D bioprinting compounds, active origami, or shape-morphing systems, employ the same procedures as 3D printing by depositing polymer/nanocomposites in consecutive layers to produce 3D objects. Notably, 4D bioprinting imparts new dimensions of transformation on time in response to external stimuli. These materials can be programmed to react with parameters of their surrounding environment and, consequently, change their forms. Therefore, 4D printing is increasingly being considered to alleviate researchersâ concerns and applied in a wide range of biomedical fields.(10) Currently, the methods of 4D printing mainly include fused deposition modeling (FDM), stereolithography apparatus (SLA), PloyJet, laser-based direct-writing (DW), and microextrusion. In addition, the printer should be carefully selected based on various types of dynamic materials. Table 1 presents a summary of printing technologies for these advanced materials.
    Table 1. Summary of the Characteristics of 4D Printing Technology
    Â characteristic
    technologyprocess timefeature detailsurface finishlayer thickness (Î¼m)propertiesrefs
    fused deposition modeling (FDM)slowroughrough100â1000The final product is sturdy, stable, and durable..(11)â()()()(15)
    stereolithography (SLA)fastfinegood50â250one of the most powerful and versatile of all solid freeform techniques(11), (13),(16), (17)
    PloyJetfastfinegood16â32multimaterial printing(11)â()(13), (18)
    laser-based direct-writing (DW)mediumfinegood0.1â300a variety of precursors or materials, such as solid, liquid, gas, and cells/DNA(11), (19)()â(21)
    microextrusionfastfinegood50â1000Viscous bioinks are relatively simple; the printing process does not involve high temperature, high-energy radiation, and powder bed.(22)()â(24)
    This review discusses the functionalities and features of these materials that must respond to external stimuli, along with their chemistry of responsivity. In addition, the biomedical applications of 4D printing are discussed and summarized according to the materials, printing type, response to stimuli, and deformation type. Then, the current limitations and directions are also presented to provide a basis for future research.

    2. 4D Dynamic Materials

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Dynamic materials involve an extensive range of various compounds with a unique potential for different industrial and biomedical applications.(25) The specific features that essentially render these materials âdynamicâ are their capability to respond to very small changes in their surrounding environment.(26) These polymers and the incorporated nanofillers must be biocompatible to be employed in the clinic. Various parameters affect their biocompatibility, e.g., the surface charge and size, and the interaction with proteins. The size and surface chemistry of filler particles alter the interactions with cells and their cellular uptake. These features are probably associated with the membrane-wrapping process. Small nanocompounds exhibit fewer ligand-to-receptor interactions than larger particles.(27) For instance, positively charged chitosan-coated nanoparticles enhance clot penetration (thrombolyticity) through an electrostatic interaction with fibrin, which is negatively charged.(28) In another study, peptide-functionalized gold NPs were fabricated with different surface charges and sizes, and their effects on the integrity of the bloodâbrain barrier (BBB) were investigated. Based on the results, (I) small (1.4 nm) gold NPs substantially altered the BBB integrity and induced cell death, and (II) particles with a negative surface charge impaired the BBB passage.(29)
    Advances in biocompatible materials, including natural and synthetic polymers, have enabled the 3D printing of functional living tissues to address the need for organ transplantation.(30â32) In general, the 3D bioprintable materials are very restricted(33,34) to some biocompatible polymers, e.g., modified block copolymers,(35) sodium alginate, chitosan, and acrylates-based polymers.(36,37)

    2.1. Functionality and Chemistry

    These materials can be preprogrammed to provide a corresponding and predictable deformation in response to specific stimuli after 3D printing.(38,39) The types of deformation are classified as one-way, two-way, and multiway deformation (Figure 1).(40) In the next section, we discuss how these materials are designed and the features they must possess to respond to external stimuli, such as the functional groups or nanosized filler that must be included in these systems to ensure their dynamic responsiveness for a specific medical application.
    In general, three different types of materials respond to the external stimuli listed below (Figure 2).
    (I)

    Physical stimuli, including temperature, light, ultrasounds, and magnetic and electric field. The following approaches have been used to prepare physical stimuli-responsive materials (Figure 2):

    • Magnetic stimulus-responsive materials: Magnetically responsive materials are fabricated by incorporating magnetic nanostructures, such as Fe, Co, Ni, Fe2O3, Fe3O4, CuFe2O4, ZnFe2O4, NiFe2O4, etc. These nanocompounds have been employed in situ (embedded) or decorated or mixed with the desired materials.(27,41â43) One clear example of 4D-printed magnetic stimulus-responsive nanocomposites is iron oxide NP-embedded poly(N-isopropylacrylamide-co-acrylic acid) hydrogels to achieve remote control by applying magnetic fields.(44) A magnetically responsive ink was fabricated using polydimethylsiloxane and Fe particles to develop reversible 4D-printed bio-objects for medical applications.(45)

    • Electrical stimulus-responsive materials: These materials respond to an applied electric field by altering their shape and/or size. They are fabricated by embedding inherently conductive polymers, i.e., polyacetylene, polypyrrole, polyaniline, polythiophene, and their derivatives and copolymers, or conductive nanoarchitectures such as carbon-based nanomaterials and metals NPs.(46,47) For instance, the origami robot was fabricated by folding a polypyrrole film as a 4D-printed electro-active material.(48)

    • Light-responsive materials: Photoresponsive materials are quite special materials; they are capable of responding to light by altering their polarity, hydrophilicity, and conformation. They have been constructed from conducting polymers or polymers containing azobenzene, stilbene, spiropyran, fulgide, and diarylethene or photosensitive-nanometals, such as Pt, Au, TiO2, NPs, etc. For example, one method for the fabrication of light-responsive materials is embedding photochromic dyes (chromophores), such as spiropyrans and azobenzenes, in the polymer matrix. Another method involves the incorporation of photoresponsive metal NPs or photochromic dyes into a polymer matrix.(25) The most common light-sensitive polymers in 4D-printed bio-objects consist of poly(N-isopropylacrylamide) functionalized with spirobenzopyran and hydrogels based on 4,4â²-azodibenzoic acid, Î±-cyclodextrin, and dodecyl-modified poly(acrylic acid).(49) For instance, by adding monoacrylate and urethane diacrylate as the linear chain builder and cross-linker, respectively, to prototype elastomers, a UV sensitive elastomer has been fabricated for passive 4D printing.(50)

    • Temperature-responsive materials: Thermosensitive materials are probably the most commonly used platform in 4D printing applications. Responsive polymer solutions, such as poly(N-isopropylacrylamide), poly(N-vinylcaprolactam), gelatin, collagen, and poly(ethylene glycol), as well as shape memory polymers, e.g., poly(Îµ-caprolactone) dimethacrylate, polycaprolactone triol, soybean oil epoxidized acrylate, poly(ether urethane) (PU), and poly(lactic acid) (PLA), are two of the most common types of thermosensitive polymers employed in 4D printing systems.(49) Shape memory polymers are generally preferred in 4D printing due to their ease of printability and glass transition temperatures higher than their operating temperature. Generally, shape memory polymers are modified with other components to make them printable and employ their specific properties.(51,52) For instance, self-healing shape memory polymers used for the development of 4D printing were synthesized from benzyl methacrylate as a linear chain builder, poly(ethylene glycol) dimethacrylate as a cross-linker and polycaprolactone as a self-healing agent.(53) In another study, printable waterborne platforms based on polyurethane/carboxymethylcellulose/silicon oxide NPs were utilized. These nanocomposites presented shape memory behaviors at various temperatures.(54) A 4D-printed material based on liquid crystal elastomers as thermosensitive materials has also been prepared from 1,4-bis-[4-(6-acryloyloxhexyloxy)benzoyloxy]-2-methylbenzene liquid crystal monomer and n-butylamine as a chain extender in the presence of a photoinitiator.(55)

      Notably, although these thermoresponsive 4D materials differ from injectable thermosensitive hydrogels, they may have some similar components. Thermosensitive hydrogels have been prepared from amphiphilic materials, e.g., polymers containing both hydrophobic (âCH2â chains and hydrocarbons rings) and hydrophilic segments (amine, hydroxyl, carboxylic and sulfate). For instance, the amphiphilic block copolymers poly(ethylene oxide)-poly(propylene oxide) copolymers (Poloxamers or Pluronics, PPOâPEO-PPO) undergo thermal gelation. At room temperature, they are low-viscosity liquids, but at body temperature, they solidify and become a gel.(56,57)

    • Ultrasound-responsive materials: Ultrasound is used in several fields, including ultrasonic devices for chemical processes and bioimaging in medicine.(58) Ultrasound-responsive polymers are categorized into biodegradable (such as polyglycolides and polylactides) and nonbiodegradable polymers, e.g., poly(ethylene-co-vinyl acetate) and poly(lactide-co-glycolide).(59,60) In general, most polymers are ultrasound-sensitive; in the presence of a high ultrasound intensity, the polymer bonds are cleaved. However, related factors, e.g., the wave intensity, the exposure duration, and the reaction environment, increase the sensitivity of the polymers, for example, micelles produced from poly(ethylene oxide-b-lactic acid) including hydrophilic poly(ethylene oxide) and hydrophobic poly(lactic acid) blocks that are exposed to ultrasound release of the entrapped Nile red dye.(61) By blending or fabricating composites of the aforementioned polymers, ultrasound-responsive materials have been achieved for 4D printing. Ultrasound has been employed as a trigger for shape recovery. For instance, a hydrogel-based on melamine-embedded poly(vinyl alcohol) deforms at room temperature, while shape fixation occurs by freezing this platform. The freezing process fixes the poly(vinyl alcohol) segments, and ultrasound is used to induce localized heating and subsequently restore the shape under water. Water indeed has been employed as a trigger for shape recovery, which may be beneficial for biomedical applications.(62,63)

    (II)

    Chemical stimuli consisting of pH and ionic concentrations.

    • pH-responsive materials: Indeed, these materials are the polymers that will respond to the pH variations of the surrounding environment by changing their dimensions. They swell or collapse depending on the pH of the medium pH, due to the existence of specified functional groups in the polymer chain. In addition, these materials are categorized into two classes: acidic polymers (contain âCOOH and âSO3H groups) and basic polymer (contain âNH2 groups). The response mechanisms for both polymers are the same, as only their stimulus differs.(25) The pH-responsive polymers used in 4D-printed materials are classified as natural biopolymers such as hyaluronic acid, chitosan, alginic acid, dextran, and gelatin or synthetic polymers, e.g., poly(acrylic acid), poly(histidine), poly(aspartic acid), and poly(l-glutamic acid).(49) For instance, pH was used to induce the shape recovery of a polymer synthesized by cross-linking Î²-cyclodextrin-modified alginate and diethylenetriamine-modified alginate.(64)

    • Moisture-responsive materials: Moisture-responsive materials are common materials containing hydrophilic functional groups, such as âCOOH, âNH2, âSO3H, and âOH, with cross-links.(65) Hydrogels are a class of polymer materials with amazing moisture-responsive networks because their hydrophilicity allows the material to swell to a volume greater than the original volume. Biocompatibility and ease of printing with direct ink writing are their unique advantages.(66) Notably, 4D printing based on hydrogel assists with reversible stimulation, and thus the swelling and shrinking of the hydrogel network occur after the absorption and evaporation of the solvent, respectively. For instance, a bioink based on a cellulose fibril-loaded soft acrylamide matrix has been fabricated using the four-dimensional printing method. Moisture-responsive systems mostly show pH sensitivity due to the presence of hydrophilic functional groups, such as âCOOH, âNH2, âSO3H, and âOH. The architectures of the composite hydrogel are altered when they are immersed in water.(67)

    (III)

    Biological stimuli, such as glucose, enzymes, and other biomolecules.

    • In the human body, biological activities generally depend on controlled communication through pathways involving biological molecules such as cholesterol, glucose, and proteins. For instance, an adjustment of blood glucose levels is mediated by insulin secretion in response to the blood sugar level. A signaling molecule/ligand must be decorated on a polymer or nanoparticles to prepare dynamic materials that bind to a specific molecule/receptor in the human body (Figure 3). The functionalized particles/polymers must be incorporated into the printable materials to prepare a 4D material that responds to biological cues. The ligand binds to only one or a few target receptors in the body. The binding of a ligand to a receptor may alter its shape or activity, facilitating the transmission of a signal or directly producing a change inside the cell.(65,68â70) However, biological responses are not a separate category. They function in combination with other responsive materials. For instance, for targeted delivery, after the alteration of the shape of a 4D material by another stimulus (such as pH and temperature), the bio-object releases its contents or binds to an enzyme or cell receptor in the human body. The binding/interaction step is similar to biosensors that bind/interact with biological components, such as monosaccharides, cells, nucleic acids, hydrogen peroxide, and glucose.

    2.2. Multiresponsive Materials

    Some materials respond to multiple stimuli or the combination of multiple stimuli. These advanced materials have experienced greater popularity due to their multidimensional responses. Multisensitivity is able to tune the properties of these materials in multiple ways, which increases their sensitivity and specificity. Multiresponsive polymer materials are capable of conformational and chemical changes and have been applied in various fields, e.g., tissue engineering, coatings, sensors, and soft robotics.(71) Many multiresponsive polymers have been described, such as polymers displaying thermomagnetic, thermopH, thermolight, and thermohumidity sensitivity. For instance, thermosensitive hydrogels containing polymers with carboxylic acid functionality respond to temperature and pH (Figure 4A). The system undergoes gelation at the pH of 6 to 7 (e.g., in the infarcted heart) at 37 Â°C, while the hydrogel does not solidify at the physiological pH (e.g., in the blood at pH â¼ 7.4) at 37 Â°C.(72) In another study, pH-thermoresponsive 3-azido-2-hydroxypropyl methacrylate-based polymers were synthesized for use in biomedical materials by combining atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP) and a click chemistry reaction.(73)
    The combination of temperature-responsive polymers with magnetic sensitivity has been proposed for soft robotic applications. Poly(N-isopropylacrylamide-coacrylic acid) and iron oxide NPs were used to prepare thermomagnetically responsive hydrogels.(44) The incorporation of magnetic particles into the thermosensitive polymer was remotely directed by an external magnetic field.
    Thermosensitive polymers containing the azobenzene chromophore play a major role in temperature- and light-responsive materials. Azobenzene-based compounds exhibit attractive features; for instance, depending on the irradiation wavelength, they are capable of undergoing photoisomerization from trans to cis forms and vice versa.(75) Another interesting example of light- and temperature-sensitive materials is thermoresponsive P(NIPAM-co-NBDAE)-b-P(NIPAM-co-SPMA) brush-coated silica NPs that collapse within a wide range of temperatures (Figure 4B).(74)
    Triply responsive polymers based on poly(N-isopropylacrylamide)-containing azobenzene moieties were reported by Liu et al.(76) These copolymer hydrogels were responsive to temperature, light, and pH. Another study designed hyperbranched poly(ether amine)-containing azobenzene that responded to a combination of different stimuli, e.g., temperature, pH, ionic strength, and light.(77)

    3. Mechanism and Function

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    This section provides additional details about the chemistry and mechanism of action of 4D advanced materials, e.g., how they behave and respond, as well as how the translation to function occurs upon exposure to an external stimulus.
    The dynamic responsive materials used as compounds sensitive to external triggers, biological signals, or pathological abnormalities have been increasingly considered for the development of next-generation biomedical devices. The printed materials used as biomedical devices must possess two properties to be used as 4D materials. They should be printable and sensitive to a stimulus. The sensitivity is achieved by the polymer matrix or by incorporating an additive/filler. For instance, Atoufi et al. developed a biocompatible stimuli-responsive conducting agarose/alginate-aniline tetramer scaffold for the controlled release of dexamethasone. The authors synthesized and grafted an aniline tetramer onto sodium alginate and then added this complex to agarose as an electrical conductivity modifier to achieve a hydrogel based on an agarose/alginate-aniline tetramer (Figure 5A). Agarose was employed as a biocompatible polysaccharide with high affinity to absorb water. This carbohydrate polysaccharide was used as the polymer matrix of the hydrogels. On the other hand, the alginate-aniline tetramer was utilized as a component that responded to the electrical field. In an aqueous medium, the materials self-assemble into vesicles. In the presence of an electrical field, the printed conductive vesicles are disrupted during oxidation/reduction processes, leading to the release of dexamethasone (Figure 5B,C).(78,79)
    Sometimes the polymer matrix also responds to an external stimulus. In this case, additional components and fillers are not needed. In one study, an elastomer actuator based on liquid crystalline polymers (LCPs) was employed as a soft, responsive ink. The macromonomer contained acrylate groups that participated in the photopolymerization reaction.(80) Then, the reactive end groups in the ink subsequently undergo free radical polymerization in the presence of Irgacure 369 as an ultraviolet (UV) photoinitiator. The temperature-induced mesogen disorder in the printed device results in contraction along the director and expansion along the orthogonal direction. This behavior, along with the ability to locally define the liquid crystalline director in the printed device, allows the programmed material to respond to temperature (Figure 6AâE).(81)
    In addition, 4D dynamic materials have also been used to prepare self-healing systems. Phosphate-modified polymers bind to metal cations and have been applied for self-healing, shape memory devices, as well as for the controlled release of biomolecules and drugs from hydrogels.(83,84)
    The ionoprinting of multimetals, e.g., iron and vanadium, as cross-linking agents, has been employed to create and control the actuation of hydrogels. Programmable hydrogels were fabricated by combining ionoprinting and redox chemistry. In the presence of an ascorbic acid solution, the device folds into three-dimensional architectures. Ascorbic acid is only able to reduce the Fe3+, as it is too weak to reduce the V3+. Therefore, while the Fe3+ is being reduced, the hinge unfolds because of the weakening of ionic cross-links and diffusion of the cations into the hydrogel. Simultaneously, the V3+ remains unchanged and retains the ionic cross-linking environment created through ionoprinting (Figure 6F,G). In a study conducted by Lee et al., the effect of the metal ion type on the movements of hydrogel actuators was investigated using catechol-containing hydrogels. The rate of alteration of the curvature significantly depended on the strong interaction between catechol and the metal ion based on the coordination chemistry in the following order: Ti4+ â« Fe3+ â Al3+ â Cu2+ > Zn2+.(85)
    In addition to shape-changing systems, some 4D dynamic materials respond in other ways, e.g., light emission. For instance, pH-responsive hydrogel nanocomposites based on poly(vinyl alcohol) and cross-linked polyacrylamide-containing carbon nanoparticles were fabricated using free radical polymerization (Figure 7A).(86) Upon changes in the pH, the shape of the nanocomposites changes, and fluorescence occurs simultaneously. In fact, in basic solutions (high pH values), the temporary shape of the nanocomposite is fixed along with the emergence of fluorescence. In contrast, under acidic conditions, the original shape is restored, and the fluorescence disappears. The mechanism underlying the switchable fluorescence properties of the nanocomposites is ascribed to the protonation and deprotonation of carboxyl groups on the surface of carbon quantum dots in acidic and alkaline solutions, respectively (Figure 7B). At low pH, the âCOOH, âOH, and âB(OH)2 groups on the surface of the carbon quantum dots form hydrogen bonds with the âOH groups of poly(vinyl alcohol) and âNH2 groups of polyacrylamide. In contrast, at high pH, the hydrogen bonds between the carbon quantum dots and poly(vinyl alcohol) break and a boronic ester structure forms. Overall, this structure enhances the mechanical properties (storage modulus), as the interaction of the boronic ester bond is stronger than the hydrogen bond (Figure 7C).(86â88)
    In another study, a double network hydrogel was fabricated with bonds between alginate and calcium ions, as well as between diol ester and phenylboronic acid, as temporary cross-links. Although this hydrogel with triple shape memory properties was not fabricated with 3D printers, the components have the potential to be processed using 3D systems. In this hydrogel, chemically cross-linked poly(acrylamide) was employed as the first network, which established the permanent shape. After the deformation of a straight hydrogel, calcium ions were applied to cross-link alginate in the aqueous media that tightly locked the deformation, resulting in the first stabilized temporary shape. Subsequently, bond formation between diol ester and phenylboronic acid under basic conditions led to the fixation of the second temporary shape (Figure 8).(89)
    Biobased materials, e.g., plant oil-based resins, have also been functionalized and applied in 4D devices. For instance, soybean oil epoxidized acrylate (SOPA) was recently introduced as a renewable and biocompatible resin for stereolithography. This macromonomer is readily polymerized by a UV laser. The schematic illustrating the shape memory mechanism of SOPA is presented in Figure 9.

    4. Biomedical Devices and Platforms

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    4.1. Scaffolds

    Since the structure or function of advanced materials prepared using 4D printing can change over time, which provides the cells with the stress they need, it exhibits great potential to be applied as a scaffold.(7,91) Miao et al. used soybean oil epoxidized acrylate to create a shape memory scaffold using SLA that would support the growth of human bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs). The scaffold was fixed to a temporary shape at â18 Â°C and completely restored to its initial shape at 37 Â°C, while promoting the good attachment and proliferation of hMSCs.(92)
    Polycaprolactone (PCL), a biocompatible and clinically approved biomaterial, is one the most frequently employed polymers in 4D bioprinting. For instance, a series of new shape memory polymers with great biocompatibility and adjustable shape-changing effects have been produced using polycaprolactone triol, castor oil, and multi-isocyanate.(93) Compared with PCL, these polymers promote greater levels of adhesion, proliferation, and differentiation of mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs).
    Both of the aforementioned materials exhibit good deformation characteristics and biocompatibility, but none of these studies showed whether the physical stimulation of the deformation of the materials impaired the behaviors of cells. Although the recovery temperature is less than or equal to 37 Â°C, the morphology and function of the cells must be monitored during heating, which was not investigated. More sophisticated in vitro and in vivo analyses are needed to address the possible problems and improve the applications of these materials in tissue engineering.
    Additionally, in tissue engineering, studies have been conducted to modulate cells using mechanical stimulation to improve the functionality of the final tissue product.(94â96) In this regard, Hendrikson et al. used polyurethane to print the 4D shape memory polymers with controllable time-dependent shape changes that stimulate morphological changes in cells. During scaffold deformation, the cells seeded on the scaffold and their nuclei are elongated by mechanical stimulation. The shape of the scaffolds is restored from the temporary shape to the initial shape at 37 Â°C, allowing them to be implanted into patients using minimally invasive surgery. They have been used for the regeneration of tissue that changes mechanically with physical activity.(97)
    Currently, the scaffolds only exert a single type of deformation on the cells, and the long-term effects of a single mechanical stimulus on cell differentiation are expected to be minimal. Therefore, further studies are needed to identify more suitable shape memory polymers and nanocomposites and to optimize the programming cycle for shape recovery, ensuring that a variety of mechanical stimuli can be applied.(97)

    4.2. Drug/Biomolecule Carriers

    Currently, controlled drug delivery systems are attracting increasing attention. They have many advantages, including better control of drug concentration, enhanced bioavailability, prolonged residence time, decreased side effects, protection of drugs from harsh conditions, and reduced drug administration frequency.(98)
    The 4D-bioprinted materials attain precise control to carry and deliver drugs, biomolecules, and cells in a programmable manner through self-folding or self-unfolding, as well as swelling/deswelling. For instance, a thermally responsive theragripper (TG) composed of biodegradable poly(propylene fumarate) (PPF) and biocompatible poly(N-isopropylacrylamide-co-acrylic acid) (pNIPAM-AAc) has facilitated the controlled release of the drug through its layers and pores. The TGs are closed at temperatures greater than 32 Â°C, which allows them to spontaneously grasp the tissue as they enter the body from a cold state. This property allows the TGs to be effectively immobilized at a specific site and prolongs the release of the drug, thereby better controlling the drug concentration and reducing the side effects of the drug.(99) Additionally, human patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and gastrointestinal (GI) cancer may benefit from this research if the materials are applied in the clinic because unpleasant drug delivery methods and systemic medications for chemotherapy drugs will be avoided.(99,100) Although TG has many advantages, it exerts little effect on the small intestine, which is inaccessible to the endoscope.(99)
    In another study, Ceylan et al. utilized the proteolytic degradation properties of gelatin methacryloyl to prepare biodegradable microrobot-based hydrogels for targeted drug delivery to release a drug by sensing the matrix metalloproteinase 2 (MMP-2) enzyme in the environment (Figure 10).(70) Alignment of the magnetic nanoparticles defines an easy axis normal to the helical axis; thus, when the nanoparticles are in the human body, they rotate in response to rotating magnetic fields. Generally, MMP-2 degrades collagen proteins that constitute the major structure of the extracellular matrix during the tissue remodeling process.(101,102) However, tumor metastasis in a specific area will cause a local increase in MMP-2 levels.(103,104) Therefore, this pathologically elevated MMP-2 concentration will accelerate the release of the drug through the enzymatic degradation of the hydrogel. In addition, after the hydrogel degrades and releases the drug, it leaves no detectable toxic residues.(70)
    Currently, nanoparticles are progressively employed as biomolecule carriers because of their advantages in improving drug solubility and bioavailability, changing the biodistribution, improving the pharmacokinetics, and decreasing the side effects.(105â109) The pH of the human tumor microenvironment is reported to range from 5.7 to 7.8.(110,111) Therefore, Griset et al. fabricated pH-responsive cross-linked nanostructures. These nanoparticles are hydrophobic at neutral pH and release little of their contents. At acidic pH, acid-labile protecting groups are removed, hydroxyl groups are exposed, and the nanoparticles become hydrophilic and subsequently swell to release their contents. In their initial state, the cross-linked nanocompounds, are hydrophobic, and upon cellular internalization, they transform into a hydrophilic structure. In aqueous media, water is absorbed by the hydrogel particles, leading to swelling and subsequently releasing the encapsulant (Figure 11). According to in vivo studies, this mode of administration more effectively prevents the establishment of lung cancer than traditional paclitaxel delivery methods.(112)

    4.3. Sensors

    Dynamic materials are designed to react to specific external stimuli, such as temperature, magnetic fields, and variations in the moisture content, pH, and ionic concentration of the surrounding environment.(56,57,113) These properties enable researchers to detect changes in the microenvironment by observing alterations in the shape or function of the dynamic materials. For instance, a liquid-responsive hydrogel film with reversible movement has been fabricated based on poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate.(114) In the presence of different humidity levels, the film exhibits varying degrees of pink color, spontaneous deformation, and movement. In addition, polymeric dynamic materials possess a variety of different characteristics that enable each of these functions to be activated by a specific external stimulus.(115)
    ThÃ©rien-Aubin et al. described a method to achieve multiple shape deformation of a composite gel sheet in response to different external stimuli. The composite gel sheet contains four synthetic polymers, poly(2-acrylamido-2-methylpropane) sulfonic acid (PAMPS), poly(acrylamide-co-butyl methacrylate) (AA-co-BMA), poly(NIPAm-co-dimethylamino-ethyl methacrylate) (NIPAm-co-DMAEMA), and poly(hydroxyl ethylacrylamide-co-N-isopropylacrylamide) (HEAm-co-NIPAm), which respond to ions, pH, carbon dioxide, and thermal stimulation, respectively. In the composite gel sheet, different regions undergo swelling or shrinkage at specific locations in response to changes in the temperature, pH, ionic strength, or carbon dioxide supply, resulting in a change in the shape of the sheet.(116)
    In summary, both of the aforementioned materials possess great potential for applications in sensors, actuation, and soft robotics.(114,116) Currently, these materials require additional experimental analyses, and the changes in response to the stimulus are unable to be accurately expressed. Thus, materials must be developed, which are more sensitive and show a significant change in response to a small stimulus, and are needed to provide opportunities for future clinical trials.
    When humans perform outdoor activities, they must monitor the time of UV exposure. Although UV exposure contributes to the production of vitamin D, excess UV exposure is associated with skin cancer.(117â119) Therefore, devices for monitoring UV exposure have been the focus of many studies.(120â122) A flexible, power-free, and lightweight cumulative UV trilayer sensor has been developed for this purpose. The layer of the UV-responsive polymer was inserted between the polyethylene naphthalate (PEN) layer and polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) layer. The photochemical reaction of o-nitrobenzyl (ONB)-modified PMA and dimerization of the photocleavage products changes the color of this sensor from transparent to yellow upon exposure to UV light, and the yellow color deepens as the exposure time increases. Finally, the color of this sensor is quantified by calculating the yellowness index to determine the UV exposure time (Figure 12).(123)
    Although the sensor indicates the UV exposure time based on the color depth, individuals are unable to judge whether they are exposed to ultraviolet light for a long time. In addition, since the color variation of the sensor is irreversible, frequent replacement is needed. For instance, if the corresponding phone apps were developed, people would be able to scan the color of the sensor with their smartphones to determine the UV exposure time. By adding other stimuli-responsive materials, the color would be restored to transparent in the absence of the UV stimulus, similar to a rechargeable battery. As a result, the aforementioned limitations and problems may be solved.
    Other types of sensors have also been developed for monitoring biological compounds. With the increasing incidence of diabetes worldwide, researchers are focusing on developing advanced devices that monitor blood glucose levels and release insulin.(124,125) Therefore, the number of glucose-responsive materials has increased. For instance, a new glucose biosensor was fabricated by incorporating glucose oxidase and platinum nanoparticles into carbon nanotubes and polyaniline nanowires of inkjet printers.(126) This biosensor achieves a quantitative analysis of blood glucose levels through a two-step catalytic process: in the first step, glucose degradation is catalyzed by oxidase to produce hydrogen peroxide; in the second step, hydrogen peroxide degradation is catalyzed by platinum nanoparticles to produce hydroxide ions that induce the local pH change. Thereafter, the pH-responsive conductivity of the polyaniline is used as a chemical resistance sensor to detect the glucose concentration.

    4.4. Other Devices

    These materials have been used in gastric devices used for weight loss, such as ingestible electronic devices, percutaneous feeding tubes, and intragastric balloons. These gastric devices usually incorporate elastic polymer components to reduce their volume and ensure the safe transport of large objects through the esophagus.(127â129) However, due to the nondegradable nature of these elastomeric polymers, the large gastric devices may cause complications, such as intestinal obstruction.(128,130,131) Additionally, the pH of the stomach environment is 1â3, which is different from the pH â¼ 6.8 of the intestinal environment.(132)
    Zhang and colleagues developed a unique pH-responsive supramolecular polymer enteric elastomer that consists of two synthetic polymers, poly(acryloyl-6-aminocaproic acid) and poly(methacrylic acid-co-ethyl acrylate), to solve the problem of nondegradable elastic polymers. The enteric elastomer is elastic and stable in acidic environments and soluble in water under neutral conditions due to the deprotonation of carboxyl groups. In addition, cell experiments confirmed that the degradation products of an enteric elastomer are not cytotoxic. The authors used this enteric elastomer as the key component of the gastric-resident devices, making the devices easy to deliver, prolonging gastric retention, and improving safety. As the devices enter the intestine, degradation of the enteric elastomers causes the devices to become small segments for safe passage through the lower digestive tract.(132)

    5. Targeted Organs

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In this section, the potential applications of 4D dynamic biomaterials in various organs are discussed along with the results of recent studies, current issues, and possible solutions.

    5.1. Brain and Nervous System

    The nervous system consists of the brain, spinal cord, and peripheral nerves. Neurological dysfunction caused by central (brain and spinal cord) or peripheral nerve injury substantially affects various abilities in humans.(133)
    Although a large number of biological materials have been developed and used to treat peripheral nerve injury, the repair of nerve damage remains a major challenge.(134â136) Dexamethasone is commonly used to treat peripheral nerve injury (PNI) and inhibit inflammation.(137,138) Different devices, such as devices with shape memory properties, have been employed to have better repair peripheral nerve injury. For instance, a conducting scaffold was developed for the controlled release of dexamethasone in the presence of an electrical field (Figure 5B). The shape memory scaffold promoted the adhesion and proliferation of pheochromocytoma (PC12) cells, which presented a good conductivity and promoted cell signaling. By applying a voltage, the controlled electrical stimulation of dexamethasone is achieved.(78) When testing in vivo, researchers should closely monitor the content of aniline tetramer in the hydrogels. Regrettably, similar to other biomaterial studies for nerve regeneration, this study did not perform in vivo experiments and lacked corresponding data.(135,139) The appropriate method for applying a voltage locally to the organism and whether the hydrogel will overheat under electrical stimulation and cause toxic effects after degradation is unclear. Thus, much more work is still required on this hydrogel to evaluate its performance.
    In another study, Miao et al. fabricated a 4D reprogrammable nerve guidance conduit using their customized stereolithography printing platform. The conduit is composed of soybean oil epoxidized acrylate (SOEA) with 0.8% graphene. Using laser-induced gradient internal stress, the 4D dynamic process of the multiple responses of SOEA was achieved, as SOEA underwent a morphological transformation upon exposure to heat and alcohol. Moreover, the addition of graphene is advantageous to adjust the curvature of the conduit deformation and improve its conductivity and nerve differentiation.(140,141) At body temperature, the conduit autonomously restores its original roller shape to wrap the two stumps of the severed nerve, thereby improving the integration of the stumps and providing the tension needed to guide axonal regeneration. Additionally, human bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs) embedded in the conduit exhibited a highly directional arrangement and showed higher expression of neurogenic differentiation 1 (ND1), neuron-specific enolase (NSE), and neurogenin 2 (Ngn2) genes than the controls. The in vitro study confirmed the potential applications of their 4D bioprinting technology in treating both central (brain) and peripheral nerve injury.(140)

    5.2. Heart

    Atherosclerosis is one of the main causes of cardiovascular disease.(142â144) Vascular stents have been developed to treat heart diseases. For instance, a magneto-responsive material combining Fe3O4 nanoparticles with poly(lactic acid) has been fabricated by DW. The nanocomposite recovers its original shape to support the blood vessel when exposed to a magnetic field, which enables remote actuation and magnetic guidance to be implemented (Figure 13).(145) Despite these advantages, the essence is to generate heat through the magnetic field to recover the shape. In clinical medicine, the frequency of the magnetic field should be controlled between 50 to100 kHz to avoid high-temperature damage to the surrounding tissues.(146)
    Valvular heart disease is an important cause of morbidity and mortality.(147,148) Transcatheter implantation of bioprosthetic and mechanical valves has gradually become the main treatment for heart valve disease.(149,150) However, for pediatric patients, these alternatives lack self-repair and growth abilities, and they are unable to adapt to the growth of the heart valves in these patients.(149) Researchers created a variety of alternatives with growth capabilities, e.g., homologous tissue-engineered heart valves(149,151) and polymer stents,(152) to address these problems.
    Cabrera and co-workers developed polymer stents with growth potential using the FDM process.(152) In a 37 Â°C water bath simulating the temperature of the heart, the stent was gradually pushed out of the implant and self-expanded into a predesigned shape. Because the stent is manufactured using FDM, it displays a clear layered structure. At the time of degradation, cracks appear at the layered interface to accommodate the growth of the patient.(149) The biodegradability has been confirmed in vitro, but further in vivo studies are needed.(153)
    Heart failure after myocardial infarction is a leading cause of death. The present treatments are unable to restore heart function.(154) The use of bone marrow-derived stem cells to treat acute myocardial infarction has been reported to reduce the infarct size and revascularization, prevent recurrence of myocardial infarction, and improve cardiac function.(155) However, large numbers of cells will be lost using this technique.(156) Pedron et al. used photolithographic techniques to develop thermally responsive, bilayered, and biodegradable polymers that would reduce cell loss during transport.(157) The layer in which the polymers are used to culture cells is a nonreactive diacrylate triblock copolymer composed of polyethylene glycol and polylactic acid (PLA-b-PEG-b-PLA). The other layer is a stimulus-responsive material composed of poly(N-isopropylacrylamide) (PIPAAm). This system is effective at encapsulating and protecting cell clusters due to the temperature-responsive swelling behavior.

    5.3. Trachea

    The tracheobronchial tract is a channel for breathing that humidifies and filters air but may be injured by trauma. Hence, different polymer- and nanocomposite-based scaffolds possessing shape memory have been developed as airway stents. Stents are crucial devices that expand human vessels or the trachea. Various stents have been fabricated using 4D printing technology. For instance, a thermally reactive tracheal stent was fabricated from methacrylated polycaprolactone using SLA (Figure 14).(158) At body temperature, the stent expands and fits well with the airway structure without the need for surgical traction.
    In another study, Morrison et al. improved the clinical presentation of three pediatric patients with tracheobronchomalacia by implanting a bioabsorbable airway splint composed of polycaprolactone in which the shape is able to be changed over time, and the material degrades over time. Its degradation products are not toxic to the human body.(91) Based on the results of this study, complications from conventional treatment may be avoided after the implantation of the splint.

    5.4. Skin

    Skin is the largest organ in the human body and serves as a physical barrier to protect humans against external threats, e.g., pathogens and microorganisms.(159) Therefore, injured skin will be susceptible to infection. During the healing period, the pH of the uninfected wounds ranges from 5.5 to 6.5, while the pH of the infected wounds is greater than 6.5.(160,161) Thus, when the pH of a wound changes from acidic to alkaline values, a bacterial infection is generally considered to be present.(162) Various types of 3D-printed shape memory materials have been fabricated by several industries and academic institutes to reduce the wound healing time. Mirani et al. fabricated a pH-responsive GelDerm as a multifunctional hydrogel-based dressing (Figure 15).(163) GelDerm determines if an infection is present through a pH-dependent color change (e.g., the change in pH causes a corresponding color change) and releases antibiotics to the wound. This advanced material helps diagnose and treat wound infections.
    In another study, a patch containing pH and temperature sensors has been manufactured as a thermally responsive drug-loaded hydrogel and an electronic patch.(164) The pH and temperature sensors are used to provide information on wound infection and inflammation. The thermally responsive drug-loaded hydrogel releases the drug as needed based on changes in temperature. The preclinical test has confirmed the great potential of this material for treating wounds.

    5.5. Orthopedics

    Bone is a self-regenerating tissue, but the size of self-repairable bone defects and fractures is limited.(165,166) Currently, the repair of large bone defects caused by trauma, tumors, or infection still plagues clinicians.(167) Researchers have attempted to simulate the structure of biological tissue by fabricating bioscaffolds that provide good conditions for the formation of new bone to overcome this challenge.(168,169) For example, using the FDM method, scaffolds based on hydroxyapatite/polylactide were manufactured with shape recovery properties, which exhibit a temporary shape under compression and are capable of restoring their initial shapes upon heating. When the temperature is greater than the glass transition temperature, the scaffold recovers its original shape due to changes in polymer chain mobility and transformation to a thermodynamically favorable configuration with higher entropy.(170) Based on this characteristic, surgical wounds, healing time, and patient suffering are reduced, and medical services are improved.
    Biodegradable scaffolds based on natural polymers have also been designed, such as the enzyme-responsive implant based on chitosan and native starch.(171) Chitosan and starch are degraded in vivo by lysozyme and amylase, respectively.(172â174) After the implantation of the scaffold, lymphocytes and macrophages will appear around the scaffold and release lysozyme.(171) Thereafter, the scaffold is degraded by specific enzymes in the body (i.e., amylase and lysozyme) to gradually form a porous structure. The porous structure facilitates cellular attachment and migration. Therefore, at the initial stage of implantation, the implant provides sufficient mechanical strength and then forms pores after enzyme-mediated degradation in vivo to promote bone tissue regeneration. The implant efficiently eliminates the weak mechanical properties of the porous implants.(171) The biological activity of materials may be directly related to the rate at which the materials form apatite when soaked in a simulated body fluid (SBF).(175) In fact, bioactive materials capable of forming an apatite layer on the surface are critical for the development of biomaterials in bone tissue engineering.
    Dias et al. successfully produced pH-responsive and biodegradable surfaces composed of chitosan.(176) These surfaces are coupled to the films of poly(l-lactic acid) (PLLA) and bioactive glass (BG) and are used to control the biomineralization process. In their study, the formation of apatite was affected by the conformational change in chitosan in its critical pH range. Briefly, as the pH changes from acidic to neutral, the roughness of the surfaces increases, promoting the formation of apatite. Therefore, the formation of apatite is achieved by controlling the change in pH.
    When the human body is damaged or inflamed, the pH of the medium in the affected area drops to a basic pH; namely, the normal pH of 7.4 of the body fluid decreases to approximately 5.2.(177) Compared to the SBF at pH 5.4, a higher density apatite layer was observed on the surface of the material at pH 7.4.(176) This result differs from the required results for the bone repair process under pathological conditions. The surface modification of the materials is able to control the biomineralization process and effectively promote bone remodeling in vivo.

    6. Current Limitations and Future Perspectives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In the past few decades, with the remarkable development of 3D printing technology and materials science, stimuli-responsive biomaterials have begun to attract attention, and numerous studies have been conducted to provide a new era of 4D printing. Although 4D printing is an emerging technology, it has exerted positive effects on various medical and pharmaceutical industries, e.g., in tissue regeneration, medical devices, and drug delivery.(9,67,179â181)Table 2 summarizes the potential medical applications of the dynamic 4D-printed materials mentioned in this review. Since 4D printing is an emerging field, many limitations and challenges remain to be overcome.
    Table 2. Summary of the 4D-Printed Products Used in Biomedical Applicationsa
    dynamic materialsprinting typeresponse to stimulimorphing shape waybiomedical applicationref
    Fe3O4/benzophenone/polylactidedirect-writingmagnetic fieldone-waycardiovascular implant(145)
    thermoplastic copolyester elastomer (TCP)fused deposition modelingliquidone-wayvalve stent(152)
    PLA-b-PEG-b-PLA/PIPAAmphotolithographytemperaturetwo-wayheart failure treatment(157)
    methacrylated polycaprolactonestereolithographytemperatureone-waytracheal stent(158)
    PCL/HAlaser sintertensionone-waytracheobronchial splint(91)
    alginate glycerin hydrogelmicrofluidic coaxial extrusionphtwo-wayskin dressing(163)
    sodium alginate, agarose, PNIPAM, N,Nâ²-methylenebis(acrylamide)laser-machining and screen-printingtemperatureone-waypatch(164)
    polylactide/HAfused deposition modelingtemperatureone-wayorthopedic implant(170)
    chitosan and native starchnot availableenzymeone-wayorthopedic implant(171)
    chitosanplasma polymerizationpHone-waysurface modification(176)
    soybean oil epoxidized acrylatestereo lithographytemperatureone-waybiomedical scaffolds(92)
    polycaprolactone triol, castor oil and multi-isocyanatefused deposition modelingtemperatureone-waybiomedical scaffolds(93)
    polyurethanenot availabletemperatureone-waybiomedical scaffolds(97)
    PPF/pNIPAM-AAcphotolithographytemperaturemultiwaydrug delivery(99)
    gelatin methacryloyl microrobotstwo-photon polymerizationenzymesone-waydrug delivery(70)
    PEG-diacrylatephotopolymerizationhumiditytwo-waysensors(114)
    PAMPS, P(AA-co-BMA), P(NIPAm-co-DMAEMA), P(HEAm-co-NIPAm)photolithographyionic strength, pH, carbon dioxide supply or temperaturemultiwaysensors(116)
    PMA-ONB/PDMS/PENdrop castingUVone-waysensors(123)
    CNT/GOx/Pt NPsinkjet printingglucoseone-wayglucose monitoring(126)
    poly(acryloyl 6-aminocaproic acid)/poly(methacrylic acid-co-ethyl acrylate)coprecipitation and ultracentrifugationpHone-waygastric devices(132)
    agarose/alginate-aniline tetramer hydrogelnot availablevoltageone-waynerve graft(178)
    soybean oil epoxidized acrylate/graphenecustomized stereolithographyheat and alcoholmultiwaynerve graft(140)
    a

    AAc: acrylic acid. CNT: carbon nanotube. DMAEMA: dimethylamino-ethyl methacrylate. HEAm: poly(hydroxyl ethylacrylamide. PNIPAm: poly(N-isopropylacrylamide). PEG: poly(ethylene glycol). PMAA: poly(methacrylic acid).

    First, 4D printing technology is in its infancy, and its printing materials are still in the exploration stage. Indeed, a printer specifically designed for 4D printing is currently unavailable. The corresponding technology must be further improved to develop additional highly precise medical devices. However, the current printing precision and material performance are unable to meet this criterion. Second, the biological environment is complex, dynamic, and different for each person. The printed products should be adapted to the microenvironment of the organism, for instance, using microfluidic systems to apply 4D printing to biomedicine. Microfluidic systems manipulate small amounts of fluids (10â6 to 10â15 mL) through a series of channels and chambers with dimensions of tens of micrometers. The biomimetic microenvironment of microfluidic devices creates an optimal plate to reach cell biological potentials for the production of a functional tissue.(182)
    In terms of the starting materials, although many advanced polymers and nanocomposites are able to change their shape or function in response to stimulation, the materials used in biomedicine must possess some specific features, such as biocompatibility, noncytotoxic, a certain mechanical strength, and the response stimulus strength does not impair the tissues. Hence, a few dynamic materials meet the aforementioned requirements. In addition, most of the materials only respond to a single stimulus, and most of these stimuli are limited to temperature, which restricts their biological applications.
    Overall, the 3D bioprintable materials are restricted(33,34) to some biocompatible polymers, such as natural and synthetic polymers, e.g., carbohydrate polysaccharides and acrylate-based polymers. The development of new materials or advances in the functionalization of the existing monomers/polymers to allow them to be printable or improve their biocompatibility may provide opportunities to implement new devices for biomedical applications. An example of a new material developed and employed in 4D systems is soybean oil epoxidized acrylate (see section 2).(90)
    Although the 4D materials have been used to produce tissues with a complex structure, they have not been completely employed in clinical applications because the maturation of the printed tissue is still incomplete and evidence from clinical trials is lacking.(9) Therefore, the maturation of the printed tissue bio-objects must be improved in the postprinting processes, e.g., cellular coating and cell self-organization. Indeed, post-tissue maturation provides an opportunity to achieve engineered tissue bio-objects with functional properties that are comparable to the native tissue.(183)
    Despite these limitations, the prospects of 4D printing remain promising. All groundbreaking research and techniques are initially observed only at the corners at which they are exposed, while huge âicebergsâ are hidden beneath the water. Similar to the breakthrough of 4G to 5G in the communication industry, people only view it as an increase in speed, but they have not been noticed the business opportunities behind it. Moreover, with the development of engineering technology, the aforementioned limitations would naturally be eliminated. As far as adapting to the body, products could be composed of various dynamic materials to respond to a variety of stimuli, and instead of popularization, the development of personalized medical devices at the outset will help to alleviate this limitation. In conclusion, 4D printing is providing new opportunities for biomedical treatment, and thus organic and inorganic materials are becoming more suitable for use in organisms.

    1. 1
      Ji, Y.; Yang, Q.; Huang, G.; Shen, M.; Jian, Z.; Thoraval, M.-J.; Lian, Q.; Zhang, X.; Xu, F. Improved resolution and fidelity of droplet-based bioprinting by upward ejection. ACS Biomater. Sci. Eng. 2019, 5 (8), 4112â 4121, Â DOI: 10.1021/acsbiomaterials.9b00400
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      1
      Improved Resolution and Fidelity of Droplet-Based Bioprinting by Upward Ejection
      Ji, Yuan; Yang, Qingzhen; Huang, Guoyou; Shen, Mingguang; Jian, Zhen; Thoraval, Marie-Jean; Lian, Qin; Zhang, Xiaohui; Xu, Feng
      ACS Biomaterials Science & Engineering (2019), 5 (8), 4112-4121CODEN: ABSEBA; ISSN:2373-9878. (American Chemical Society)
      Bioprinting has emerged as a powerful biofabrication technol. with widespread applications in biomedical fields because of its superiority in high-throughput, high-precision, 3D structure fabrication. For bioprinting, two of the most important parameters are the printing precision (i.e., droplets resoln.) and structural fidelity (i.e., conformity of the printed objects to the design). The major factors that hinder resoln. and fidelity are gravity and impact force between printed droplets and substrate. However, existing solns. to these two issues, including decreasing droplet vol. and introducing sacrificial materials, cause other problems, such as complexity or poor biocompatibility. Here, we reported a variant 3D bioprinting technique, termed as upward bioprinting, in which the nozzle of bioprinter is overturned and the ejection direction is opposite to gravitational force. Employing this technique, we fabricated discrete droplets, continuous lines, and 3D multilayer constructs using alginate and gelatin methacrylate (GelMA). The characterizations show that the upward bioprinting could improve the resoln. and also fidelity as compared with the conventional downward bioprinting. Meanwhile, this method enables cell printing without affecting the viability. In addn., this method can be easily implemented without upgrading any hardware. Such an upward bioprinting technique could be an alternative to scale down microtissues and to fabricate 3D complex bioconstructs. We envision that the upward bioprinting, as a general method, could be extended to other bioprinting processes or applied to 3D bioprinting in outer space.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXht1elu7nF&md5=36dc0a087186091c6484da5d1b446a68
    2. 2
      Yang, Q.; Gao, B.; Xu, F. Recent advances in 4D bioprinting. Biotechnol. J. 2020, 15 (1), 1900086, Â DOI: 10.1002/biot.201900086
      [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      2
      Recent Advances in 4D Bioprinting
      Yang, Qingzhen; Gao, Bin; Xu, Feng
      Biotechnology Journal (2020), 15 (1), 1900086CODEN: BJIOAM; ISSN:1860-6768. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      4D bioprinting has emerged as a powerful technique where the fourth dimension "time" is incorporated with 3D bioprinting. In this technique, the printed bioconstructs are able to change their shapes or functionalities when triggered by either internal or external stimuli. In 4D bioprinting, the materials with/without cells enable the spatial-temporal control of the shape and/or functionality of the constructs. Using this method, researchers have printed bioconstructs that can transform into rather complex structures which are difficult to obtain directly by 3D bioprinting or other methods. Although the history of 4D bioprinting is short, rapid progress in this field is witnessed recently, with focus mainly on developing novel 4D printable materials, exploring novel methods to precisely control the process, and pursuing biomedical applications. To better understand this technique, the recent advances of 4D bioprinting, including the mechanism, structure design principles, applications in biomedical engineering, and also the facing challenges are reviewed.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhvVWit73N&md5=69d3e87ba2f317543e48c71ecccfcb1a

      Yang, Q.; Ji, Y.; Xu, F., 4D Bioprinting: Mechanism and Applications. In 3D Bioprinting in Regenerative Engineering; Khademhosseini, A.; Camci-Unal, G. Eds., CRC Press: Boca Raton, 2018; pp 337â 358.
      [Crossref],Â Google Scholar

    4. 4
      Rengier, F.; Mehndiratta, A.; von Tengg-Kobligk, H.; Zechmann, C. M.; Unterhinninghofen, R.; Kauczor, H. U.; Giesel, F. L. 3D printing based on imaging data: review of medical applications. Int. J. Comput. Assist. Radiol. Surg. 2010, 5 (4), 335â 341, Â DOI: 10.1007/s11548-010-0476-x
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      4
      3D printing based on imaging data: review of medical applications
      Rengier F; Mehndiratta A; von Tengg-Kobligk H; Zechmann C M; Unterhinninghofen R; Kauczor H-U; Giesel F L
      International journal of computer assisted radiology and surgery (2010), 5 (4), 335-41 ISSN:.
      PURPOSE: Generation of graspable three-dimensional objects applied for surgical planning, prosthetics and related applications using 3D printing or rapid prototyping is summarized and evaluated. MATERIALS AND METHODS: Graspable 3D objects overcome the limitations of 3D visualizations which can only be displayed on flat screens. 3D objects can be produced based on CT or MRI volumetric medical images. Using dedicated post-processing algorithms, a spatial model can be extracted from image data sets and exported to machine-readable data. That spatial model data is utilized by special printers for generating the final rapid prototype model. RESULTS: Patient-clinician interaction, surgical training, medical research and education may require graspable 3D objects. The limitations of rapid prototyping include cost and complexity, as well as the need for specialized equipment and consumables such as photoresist resins. CONCLUSIONS: Medical application of rapid prototyping is feasible for specialized surgical planning and prosthetics applications and has significant potential for development of new medical applications.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC3cvotl2guw%253D%253D&md5=181d5d9aedbc100dafe6d315e305e3fd
    5. 5
      Makvandi, P.; Esposito Corcione, C.; Paladini, F.; Gallo, A. L.; Montagna, F.; Jamaledin, R.; Pollini, M.; Maffezzoli, A. Antimicrobial modified hydroxyapatite composite dental bite by stereolithography. Polym. Adv. Technol. 2018, 29 (1), 364â 371, Â DOI: 10.1002/pat.4123
      [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      5
      Antimicrobial modified hydroxyapatite composite dental bite by stereolithography
      Makvandi, Pooyan; Esposito Corcione, Carola; Paladini, Federica; Gallo, Anna Lucia; Montagna, Francesco; Jamaledin, Rezvan; Pollini, Mauro; Maffezzoli, Alfonso
      Polymers for Advanced Technologies (2018), 29 (1), 364-371CODEN: PADTE5; ISSN:1042-7147. (John Wiley & Sons Ltd.)
      This study is aimed at the synthesis of antimicrobial hydroxyapatite (HAP)-based composites for dental application by stereolithog. (SLA). A micron-sized com. HAP was modified by methacrylate and quaternary ammonium salt, and, then, it was used in different amts. (namely 2.5, 5, and 10 wt%) as filler for a photocurable custom made resin for SLA. Thermal stability, microstructure, and particles size of the pristine (HAP) and modified HAP (mHAP) were evaluated by thermogravimetric anal. (TGA), X-ray diffraction (XRD), and particle size analyzer (CILAS). The suitability of each formulation for stereolithog. process was assessed by measuring viscosity, degree of conversion (DC%) by Fourier transform IR spectroscopy (FTIR), glass transition temp., and thermal stability. Photo-cured specimens for phys., mech., and antimicrobial testing were built by SLA. The flexural strength of the samples was measured using a 3-point bending test method, and the fractured surface was analyzed by SEM (SEM). The antimicrobial activity of samples was investigated against some std. microorganisms (Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, and Candida albicans), as representative Gram pos. and Gram neg. bacteria and fungus, resp. The flexural strength increased with a filler content up to 5% and slightly decreased for higher content. SEM anal. confirmed the presence of uniformly distributed HAP. The incorporation of mHAP reduced the bacterial and fungal growth in dose-dependent manner in comparison with the neat samples. Finally, a prototype of dental bite was built by SLA.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXht1Cms7fN&md5=0b09ac78b829d51dcabe3c10f9f55e37
    6. 6
      Ma, Y.; Ji, Y.; Zhong, T.; Wan, W.; Yang, Q.; Li, A.; Zhang, X.; Lin, M. Bioprinting-based PDLSC-ECM screening for in vivo repair of alveolar bone defect using cell-laden, injectable and photocrosslinkable hydrogels. ACS Biomater. Sci. Eng. 2017, 3 (12), 3534â 3545, Â DOI: 10.1021/acsbiomaterials.7b00601
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      6
      Bioprinting-based PDLSC-ECM screening for in vivo repair of alveolar bone defect using cell-laden, injectable and photocrosslinkable hydrogels
      Ma, Yufei; Ji, Yuan; Zhong, Tianyu; Wan, Wanting; Yang, Qingzhen; Li, Ang; Zhang, Xiaohui; Lin, Min
      ACS Biomaterials Science & Engineering (2017), 3 (12), 3534-3545CODEN: ABSEBA; ISSN:2373-9878. (American Chemical Society)
      Periodontitis is an inflammatory disease worldwide that may result in periodontal defect (esp. alveolar bone defect) and even tooth loss. Stem-cell-based approach combined with injectable hydrogels has been proposed as a promising strategy in periodontal treatments. Stem cells fate closely depends on their extracellular matrix (ECM) characteristics. Hence, it is necessary to engineer an appropriate injectable hydrogel to deliver stem cells into the defect while serving as the ECM during healing. Therefore, stem cell-ECM interaction should be studied for better stem cell transplantation. In this study, we developed a bioprinting-based strategy to study stem cell-ECM interaction and thus screen an appropriate ECM for in vivo repair of alveolar bone defect. Periodontal ligament stem cells (PDLSCs) were encapsulated in injectable, photocrosslinkable composite hydrogels composed of gelatin methacrylate (GelMA) and poly(ethylene glycol) dimethacrylate (PEGDA). PDLSC-laden GelMA/PEGDA hydrogels with varying compn. were efficiently fabricated via a 3D bioprinting platform by controlling the vol. ratio of GelMA-to-PEGDA. PDLSC behavior and fate were found to be closely related to the engineered ECM compn. The 4/1 GelMA/PEGDA composite hydrogel was selected since the best performance in osteogenic differentiation in vitro. Finally, in vivo study indicated a maximal and robust new bone formation in the defects treated with the PDLSC-laden hydrogel with optimized compn. as compared to the hydrogel alone and the saline ones. The developed approach would be useful for studying cell-ECM interaction in 3D and paving the way for regeneration of functional tissue.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhs1CgtrbN&md5=39a77ea6410117d48fb8ab14de0f2c4f

      [Crossref],Â Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
    8. 8
      Momeni, F.; Liu, X.; Ni, J. A review of 4D printing. Mater. Des. 2017, 122, 42â 79, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.matdes.2017.02.068
      [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      8
      A review of 4D printing
      Momeni, Farhang; Mehdi Hassani N, Seyed M.; Liu, Xun; Ni, Jun
      Materials & Design (2017), 122 (), 42-79CODEN: MADSD2; ISSN:0264-1275. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A review. Research into 4D printing has attracted unprecedented interest since 2013 when the idea was first introduced. It is based on 3D printing technol., but requires addnl. stimulus and stimulus-responsive materials. Based on certain interaction mechanisms between the stimulus and smart materials, as well as appropriate design of multi-material structures from math. modeling, 4D printed structures evolve as a function of time and exhibit intelligent behavior. Unlike 3D printing, 4D printing is time-dependent, printer-independent, predictable, and targets shape/property/functionality evolution. This allows for self-assembly, multi-functionality, and self-repair. This paper presents a comprehensive review of the 4D printing process and summarizes the practical concepts and related tools that have a prominent role in this field. Unsought aspects of 4D printing are also studied and organized for future research.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXktVGgsrc%253D&md5=38c728d0fd6f7bb6cbc87434a70a8344
    9. 9
      Gao, B.; Yang, Q.; Zhao, X.; Jin, G.; Ma, Y.; Xu, F. 4D bioprinting for biomedical applications. Trends Biotechnol. 2016, 34 (9), 746â 756, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.tibtech.2016.03.004
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      9
      4D Bioprinting for Biomedical Applications
      Gao, Bin; Yang, Qingzhen; Zhao, Xin; Jin, Guorui; Ma, Yufei; Xu, Feng
      Trends in Biotechnology (2016), 34 (9), 746-756CODEN: TRBIDM; ISSN:0167-7799. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      3D bioprinting has been developed to effectively and rapidly pattern living cells and biomaterials, aiming to create complex bioconstructs. However, placing biocompatible materials or cells into direct contact via bioprinting is necessary but insufficient for creating these constructs. Therefore, '4D bioprinting' has emerged recently, where 'time' is integrated with 3D bioprinting as the fourth dimension, and the printed objects can change their shapes or functionalities when an external stimulus is imposed or when cell fusion or postprinting self-assembly occurs. In this review, we highlight recent developments in 4D bioprinting technol. Addnl., we review the uses of 4D bioprinting in tissue engineering and drug delivery. Finally, we discuss the major roadblocks to this approach, together with possible solns., to provide future perspectives on this technol.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XltValsLY%253D&md5=0863139f620602288f5354f5d15285cd
    10. 10
      Lui, Y. S.; Sow, W. T.; Tan, L. P.; Wu, Y.; Lai, Y.; Li, H. 4D printing and stimuli-responsive materials in biomedical aspects. Acta Biomater. 2019, 92, 19â 36, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.actbio.2019.05.005
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      10
      4D Printing and Stimuli-responsive Materials in Biomedical Applications
      Lui, Yuan Siang; Sow, Wan Ting; Tan, Lay Poh; Wu, Yunlong; Lai, Yuekun; Li, Huaqiong
      Acta Biomaterialia (2019), 92 (), 19-36CODEN: ABCICB; ISSN:1742-7061. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Three-dimensional (3D) printing has revolutionized the world manufg. prodn. In biomedical applications, however, 3D printed constructs fell short of expectations mainly due to their inability to adequately mimic the dynamic human tissues. To date, most of the 3D printed biomedical structures are largely static and inanimate as they lack the time-dependant dimension. To adequately address the dynamic healing and regeneration process of human tissues, 4D printing emerges as an important development where "time" is incorporated into the conventional concept of 3D printing as the fourth dimension. As such, additive manufg. (AM) evolves from 3D to 4D printing and in the process putting stimulus-responsive materials in the limelight. In this review, the state-of-the-art efforts in integrating the time-dependent behavior of stimulus-responsive materials in 4D printing will be discussed. In addn., current literatures on the interactions between various types of stimuli (categorized under phys., chem. and biol. signals) with the assocd. stimulus-responsive materials will be the major focus in this review. Lastly, potential usage of 4D printing in biomedical applications will also be discussed, followed by tech. considerations as well as outlook for future discoveries. In this Review, we have demonstrated the significance of 4D printing in biomedical applications, in which "time" has been incorporated into the conventional concept of 3D printing as the 4th dimension. As such, 4D printing differentiates and evolves from 3D printing using stimulus-responsive materials which can actively respond to external stimuli and more sophisticated "hardware"-printer which can achieve multi-printing via math.-predicted designs that are programmed to consider the transformation of 3D constructs over time. The emphasize will be on the interactions between various types of stimuli (categorized under phys., chem. and biol. signals) with the assocd. stimulus-responsive materials, followed by tech. considerations as well as outlook for future discoveries.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXpsFWmt74%253D&md5=bd6a82da92b5bf5fb25488b2382e5c84
    11. 11
      Zheng, X.; Huang, J.; Lin, J.; Yang, D.; Xu, T.; Chen, D.; Zan, X.; Wu, A. 3D bioprinting in orthopedics translational research. J. Biomater. Sci., Polym. Ed. 2019, 30 (13), 1172â 1187, Â DOI: 10.1080/09205063.2019.1623989
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      11
      3D bioprinting in orthopedics translational research
      Zheng, XuanQi; Huang, JinFeng; Lin, JiaLiang; Yang, DeJun; Xu, TianZhen; Chen, Dong; Zan, Xingjie; Wu, AiMin
      Journal of Biomaterials Science, Polymer Edition (2019), 30 (13), 1172-1187CODEN: JBSEEA; ISSN:0920-5063. (Taylor & Francis Ltd.)
      The repair of crit.-size bone defect remains a challenge for orthopedic surgeons. With the advent of an aging society and their accompanying chronic diseases, it is becoming more difficult to treat bone defects, esp. large segmental bone defects that are caused by trauma, tumors, infections, and congenital malformations. New materials and technologies need to be developed to address these conditions. 3D bioprinting is a novel technol. that bridges the biomaterial and living cells and is an important method in tissue engineering projects. 3D bioprinting has the advantages of replacing or repairing damaged tissue and organs. The progress in material science and 3D printing devices make 3D bioprinting a technol. which can be used to create various scaffolds with a large range of advanced material and cell types. However, in regard to the widespread use of bioprinting, biosafety, immunogenicity and rising costs are rising to be concerned. This article reviews the developments and applications of 3D bioprinting and highlights newly applied techniques and materials and the recent achievements in the orthopedic field. This paper also briefly reviews the difference between the methods of 3D bioprinting. The challenges are also elaborated with the aim to research materials, manuf. scaffolds, promote vascularization and maintain cell viability.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhtFKjtr3J&md5=cdb7da2aaffa18224cad52cfb21c9c21
    12. 12
      Ngo, T. D.; Kashani, A.; Imbalzano, G.; Nguyen, K. T. Q.; Hui, D. Additive manufacturing (3D printing): a review of materials, methods, applications and challenges. Composites, Part B 2018, 143, 172â 196, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.compositesb.2018.02.012
      [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      12
      Additive manufacturing (3D printing): A review of materials, methods, applications and challenges
      Ngo, Tuan D.; Kashani, Alireza; Imbalzano, Gabriele; Nguyen, Kate T. Q.; Hui, David
      Composites, Part B: Engineering (2018), 143 (), 172-196CODEN: CPBEFF; ISSN:1359-8368. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Freedom of design, mass customization, waste minimization and the ability to manuf. complex structures, as well as fast prototyping, are the main benefits of additive manufg. (AM) or 3D printing. A comprehensive review of the main 3D printing methods, materials and their development in trending applications was carried out. In particular, the revolutionary applications of AM in biomedical, aerospace, buildings and protective structures were discussed. The current state of materials development, including metal alloys, polymer composites, ceramics and concrete, was presented. In addn., this paper discussed the main processing challenges with void formation, anisotropic behavior, the limitation of computer design and layer-by-layer appearance. Overall, this paper gives an overview of 3D printing, including a survey on its benefits and drawbacks as a benchmark for future research and development.
